posts.name: Barkın Var
posts.cooked:
The text has been cleaned up below:

The text is:  
I am trying to understand the implementation of motion followers on FRC products and since we don’t have the source code for TalonFX I am a little confused?  

As far as I know CTRE Products run a position PID to current position of time sampled state and a velocity feedforward for that state for the generated profile.  

When I was looking for open source projects I saw the moteus project and documentation explained their way of closed loop control.  

This is where I just got confused they were getting both position and velocity targets for their closed loop control and using the kd with the velocity error which I have never seen before in FRC (probably I did not see it).  

How does this approach differ from standard FRC way of following motion profiles?  

As far as I understand this approach will allow you to follow a non zero velocity ending trajectory as well is it true?

posts.name: Yishai Levy
posts.cooked: kD is akin to a kP controller applied to velocity, where velocity is the derivative of position. The FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC) PID controller doesn't require specifying target velocity because it estimates the desired velocity based on prior errors. The formula (currentError - prevError) / period calculates the velocity error. For those unfamiliar with WPILib's trapezoidal profile, it's a simpler alternative compared to the Cross The Road Electronics (CTRE) S-curve profile.

link_counts.title: Motion Profiling in Command-based — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.cooked:
Here is the cleaned-up version of the provided text:

This is where I just got confused—they were getting both position and velocity targets for their closed-loop control and using the kd with the velocity error, which I have never seen before in FRC (probably I did not see it).  

kD can be thought of as a kP gain on velocity. A position PID can be better thought of as a PID with a target velocity of zero. Motion profiles or moving inputs also generate a velocity reference and want you to keep velocity, so asking for a velocity of zero does not make sense. The solution is to pass velocity reference into both your feedforward and feedback controllers, achieving significantly better reference tracking, resulting in the velocity error term you are seeing.  

CTRE uses an S-curve profile, which is a bit harder to implement.  

Its less hard but more tedious as they require a lot more equations but are applied in exactly the same way.  

As far as I understand, this approach will allow you to follow a non-zero velocity ending trajectory as well, is it true?  

Yes. This is how you track moving inputs, but there is a caveat that you must update the velocity and position reference together such that the velocity reference is exactly the first derivative of the position reference. For example, if you want the controller to stay put in one place, the velocity reference must be zero at the end of the controller. If you don’t do this correctly, the system will stabilize somewhere where the kp gains on position and velocity (kd) reach equilibrium.  

I would actually suggest deriving the profiles by hand if you can’t find a good paper describing the math. Math is significantly easier to understand than code in terms of controls.

posts.name: Barkın Var
posts.cooked: The solution is to pass velocity reference into both your feedforwards and feedback controllers. WPILib’s profiled PID controller does not use the velocity target during calculations but tracks the moving target point. Since the target point moves with the same velocity as calculated, it likely achieves similar results. However, it still feels non-intuitive to derive velocity error from position setpoints. Additionally, calculating velocity feedforward but not implementing it with moteus could cause the controller to lag. They compensate by using torque control instead of voltage control.

it still feels counter intuitive for me to calculate the velocity error from the position set points. Think of it this way: velocity equals the derivative of position over time. Velocity error is the difference between actual and desired velocity, which simplifies to the derivative of the difference between actual and desired positions. Hence, velocity error is the derivative of position error.

posts.name: Yishai Levy
posts.cooked:
but it still feels counter intuitive for me to calculate the velocity error from the position set points  

i can totally understand why think of it like this if you’ll graph out each setpoint given to the robot it’s very trivial to find the motion profile’s target velocity at any given moment without asking it for it you simply take two points in the graph find the slope between them and that should be the exact velocity setpoint given by the motion profile  

it also handles non-zero velocity profile endings easily if the rate of change in setpoint is constant and non-zero till the last second the velocity target will also remain a non-zero constant setpoint  

do they overcome it by doing torque control instead of voltage control  

yeah since torque is proportional to acceleration zero torque should make you stay in your current velocity (if you apply kg ks and other feed forward terms correctly) kv is used to cancel back emf (basically the thing that makes motors slow down when the voltage goes down) you could say that just as a side affect it also helps you reach a cruise velocity for voltage control rather than only maintaining it because in torque control there is no back emf (the motor won’t slow down given a zero torque request) a kv wouldn’t really work and would be useless in most cases if you’ve ever tried to sys id with torque current control you can see it’ll basically return zero for the kv  

the kv equivalent for not lagging behind even without a kp for torque control is usually the ka

posts.name: Barkın Var
posts.cooked: The velocity target remains a non-zero constant setpoint if the rate of change in setpoint is constant and non-zero until the last second. However, implementing such changes with the current profiledPIDController may result in oscillations attempting to return to position a after halting motion.

posts.name: Yishai Levy
posts.cooked: In that case if you plan to stop changing the setpoint at the end of the path it will consistently do that. To achieve this the position setpoint must correspond to the integral of the velocity setpoint. Abruptly ending this process may not yield the desired results as discussed earlier. The real question is why are you creating a profile with a non-zero end velocity? This is typically done when transitioning between two controllers or setpoints in real-time and aiming to maintain the highest feasible velocity before shifting to the new setpoint. While this approach works universally it's essential to ensure consistency across different applications.

posts.name: Barkın Var
posts.cooked:
The real question should be: why are you generating a profile with a non-zero end velocity? I don’t really have a reason to generate a non-zero end velocity. I just wanted to understand the “what if” case.  

The most common case is when switching between two controllers or setpoints in real time, and wanting the first one to try and maintain the highest velocity possible before going to the other setpoint.  

Yes, we sometimes do it if we want to switch between controllers during autonomous (drive to position with trajectory following then drive to pose with PID).

posts.name: Yishai Levy
posts.cooked: Yes, we sometimes do it if we want to switch between controllers during autonomous driving to position with trajectory following then drive to pose. Yeah, autonomous was the exact same use case I had in mind. So, it should pretty much function the exact same way either way you do it, but I’d say deriving it from the position error is safer than inputting the target velocity by hand.

WPILib’s profiled PID controller does not use the velocity target during calculations but follows the moving target point. Since the target point moves with the same velocity as calculated, it likely achieves similar results as understood. However, assuming this is true, it will track the target poorly due to significant phase lag. When near the setpoint, the kd gain tries to decelerate to zero, which isn’t desired. Instead, the system should maintain the desired non-zero velocity, hence requiring the velocity error term.

It still feels counterintuitive to calculate velocity error from position setpoints. Velocity is the first time derivative of position, and the formula provides a simple discrete method to approximate this derivative.

The real question is why generate a profile with non-zero end velocity. Common reasons include transitioning between controllers/setpoints in real-time to maintain the highest possible velocity before changing setpoints. This approach generally works reliably unless specific use cases require otherwise.

Notably, achieving velocity continuity is challenging. Poor implementation can lead to velocity discontinuities, causing unpredictable system behavior.

posts.name: Yishai Levy
posts.cooked: Alex_Y: but it is worth noting that you must have velocity continuity, which is not always trivial A good profile should be more than enough for this, which is already the intended use case

posts.name: Barkın Var
posts.cooked:
The text is:

It is not directly getting it as a parameter of a function, it is just a simple position PID but since the target position is changing with regards to wanted velocity and it uses (currentError - prevError) / period = velocityError but this approach, all should result in the same mathematical value if I understood everything correctly.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Assuming the first part is true You know you can read the source or even the javadoc and then you won't have to wrongly assume and give bad advice.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.cooked: You know you can read the entire discussion before replying to a post so you don’t have to take a post out of context and give a pointless reply distracting from the discussion? My point is that tracking a moving target without using the velocity reference as suggested by earlier posts leads to poor tracking performance for reasons listed above, which should note when reimplementing profiles in a non-FRC context (like in the original post’s title).

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: I understand your point. It doesn’t hold because that wasn’t suggested earlier in the thread, and you’re based on a misunderstanding of the library.
